overview: This subject provides an integrative learning experience and affords students the opportunity to apply the skills and knowledge acquired in previous subjects in a coherent way to solve business problems. In a business strategy simulation students are required to make decisions, assess outcomes, and compete with other management teams for resources, opportunities and markets. Each team develops a strategy for its firm and applies the subject’s concepts and frameworks, as well as the concepts and frameworks acquired in other subjects. In the process, students will discover the interaction of a firm’s production, marketing, research and development, human resources, and financial operations and observe the impact of key decisions on business performance within a competitive market.
intended learning outcomes: Explain the dynamic nature of business and the role of strategy in generating and sustaining a competitive advantage;
Analyse relevant information and evaluate the competitive environment faced by organisations;
Identify and evaluate business strategies and explain why and how a particular course of action will provide a competitive advantage; and
Analyse the capacity for strategy implementation within an organisation given an understanding of structure, culture, systems, governance mechanisms and stakeholder relationships.

necessary pre-requisite: Completion of a minimum of 62.5 credit points of study
alternate pre-requisite: Admission into the 150pt Program course entry point in the MC-MGMT Master of Management

necessary pre-requisite: Completion of a minimum of 112.5 credit points of study
alternate pre-requisite: Admission into the MC-MGMT Master of Management

necessary pre-requisite: Completion of a minimum of 50 credit points of study
alternate pre-requisite: Admission into or selection of one of the following:
MC-MGMTAFN Master of Management (Accounting and Finance)
Students are encouraged to take the subject in their final semester of study where practical.

assessments.timing: First half of the teaching period

assessments.description: Capstone Simulation (groups of 4-5), approximately 5 hours work per week across semester. 40 hours (of work required)
assessments.timing: Second half of the teaching period

Summer Term.Contact hours: 36 hours (two 3 hour sseminars per week for 6 weeks)

Prescribed texts: There are no specifically prescribed or recommended texts for this subject.
